_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: General industry guidelines published by aqua-ammonia vendors.
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Aboveground Storage Tank and ancillary valves, pumps, and process piping.
_prev_prog_2.Description:
The Fertilizer Manager implements the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Risk Management Program (RMPr) for the Storage & Handling of aqueous ammonia at this facility and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed. The RMPr describes the Accident Prevention Program that includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, and Emergency Response.  Equipment included under this covered process is a single 16,700-gallon stationary storage tank and ancillary piping and valves.



Helena receives aqueous ammonia by a vendor that transports the aqueous ammonia with a commercial tanker truck. The commercial tanker truck is temporarily parked on the Facility property while the aqueous ammonia is transferred to the on-site storage tank. The transfer process from the commercial truck is performed by the commercial tanker truck operator (Contractor). Helena does not own or operate the commercial tanker truck. The Contractor is responsible to Helena for complying with relevant operation and training procedures and documentation. At a minimum, the Contractor must (1) have in place and certify compliance with applicable and relevant DOT and OSHA regulations, (2) make available to Helena and EPA upon request any contractor-related documentation necessary to demonstrate compliance, and (3) certify that it has in place emergency shut-down procedures for ammonia unloading operations and that its? OSHA and DOT programs comply with federal, state, and local regulatory requirements. Further, Helena will provide a copy of its Contingency Plan and RMPr for review upon request by the Contractor.

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: General industry guidelines published by aqua-ammonia vendors.
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Automated Logic System; Valves with air actuators
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Blender and ancillary process piping, pumps, valves, and cooling system.
_prev_prog_2.Description:
The Fertilizer Manager implements the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Risk Management Program (RMPr) for the Blending of aqueous ammonia at this facility and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed. The RMPr describes the Accident Prevention Program that includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, and Emergency Response. Equipment items included under this covered process are a single 16,700-gallon stationary storage tank and ancillary pump, piping and valves, a blending tank, and a heat exchanger.



Helena transfers aqueous ammonia from the 16,700-gallon storage tank to the blender where it is mixed with other ingredients.  The resulting fertilizer solution (which is not a covered chemical) is cooled with a non-contact heat exchanger before being transferred to a storage tank.

_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: The Association of American Railroads; DOT for railcars
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Vehicle or Projectile Strike, Vandalism, Theft, or Terrorism
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Railcar inspection only.  The railcar owner is responsible for maintenance.
_prev_prog_2.Description:
The Fertilizer Manager implements the Risk Management Plan (RMP) and Risk Management Program (RMPr) for the Railcar Storage of anhydrous ammonia at this facility and is assisted by other Helena staff as directed. The RMPr describes the Accident Prevention Program that includes Safety Information, Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Compliance Audits, Incident Investigation, and Emergency Response. Equipment included under this covered process is a single anhydrous ammonia railcar and ancillary valves.



Helena may receive anhydrous ammonia by railcar. The railcar is temporarily parked on the Facility property until the fertilizer blending process is completed.  The anhydrous ammonia is transferred from the railcar to a Mobile Pipe Reactor (MPR) during the fertilizer blending process.  Making connection to the railcar and transferring the anhydrous ammonia from the railcar to the MPR is performed by Independent Fertilizer Contractor (i.e. Owner/Operator of the MPR). Helena does not own or operate the railcar. The anhydrous ammonia vendor is responsible to Helena and the Department of Transportation (DOT) for providing railcars that meet DOT standards. Helena inspects the railcars and their markings to

ensure that they are within their operating window and are not leaking when they arrive onsite.

_prev_prog_3.MH_OtherType: Failure to maintain water and acid flow to the process, vehicle strike, vandalism, theft, terrorism.
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Annual inspection of the MPR and ancillary pumps, piping, and transfer hoses
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The Fertilizer Manager implements the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and combined Risk Management Plan (RMP) Program (PSM/RMPr) covered process elements for the Blending of anhydrous ammonia at this Facility and is assisted by other trained Helena staff as directed. The PSM/RMPr includes all Program 3 Accident Prevention Program elements: Management System, Employee Participation, Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis, Operating Procedures, Training, Contractor, Pre-Startup Review, Mechanical Integrity, Hot Work Permit, Management of Change, Incident Investigation, Emergency Response, and Compliance Audits. Equipment included under this covered process includes a railcar of anhydrous ammonia and a mobile pipe reactor (MPR) including ancillary pumps, piping, transfer hoses and valves. 



An Independent Fertilizer Reacting Contractor (i.e. Owner/Operator of the MPR) operates this fertilizer blending process and is responsible for training its personnel and managing the anhydrous ammonia in accordance with its PSM.

_emerg_resp.FR_OtherRegulation: This is a non-responding facility and it coordinates its response activities with the LEPC and local Fire Department. Notification information and procedures are provided in its Contingency Plan.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



The Helena Agri-Enterprises, LLC (Helena) Pasco, WA Facility has submitted this updated electronic RMP in compliance with the provisions of the Clean Air Act 112 (r) as codified by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency at 40 CFR Part 68. 



This electronic submittal provides conservative estimates of the offsite consequences of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia from the Pasco, WA Facility located at 1010 East Kartchner, Pasco, WA 99301.  The electronic RMP summarizes the policies and procedures implemented by the Pasco, WA Facility to minimize the likelihood of an accident.  The electronic RMP also summarizes the actions that the Pasco, WA Facility has taken to ensure that a response to a release will be implemented in a proper and timely manner.



PURPOSE FOR UPDATING RMP



Helena is submitting this to reflect a change in the Program Level (i.e. 2 to 3).  The Facility is planning to resume the blending of Ammonium Polyphosphate (APP) Fertilizer which involves bringing anhydrous ammonia in by railcar and a Mobile Pipe Reacting (MPR) Contractor in to perform the APP fertilizer blending.



The Facility will continue to operate the Aqua Ammonia Storage and Handling, and Aqua Ammonia Fertilizer Blending covered processes.  All relevant sections for a Program 2 and 3 PSM/RMP have been reviewed and/or updated.  The updates are reflected in both the EPA RMP Report and the Facility PSM/RMPr Program Document.  



It is important to note that the maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that will be stored and handled at the Facility is a single railcar (145,680 lbs).  Because the MPR is connected to the railcar when blending, the quantity of anhydrous ammonia is double counted in this EPA RMP.  This same scenario is applicable to the aqua ammonia.  Specifically, the maximum quantity of aqua ammonia is a single AST (26,250 lbs).  Because the fertilizer blender is connected to the AST, the quantity of aqua ammonia is double c

ounted in this EPA RMP.



FACILITY



The Pasco, WA Facility is an agriculture retail and fertilizer blending chemical facility that operates four (4) covered processes including: Covered Process 1: Railcar Storage (Anhydrous Ammonia); Covered Process 2: Fertilizer Blending using anhydrous ammonia; Covered Process 3: Storage and Handling (Aqua Ammonia); and Covered Process 4: Fertilizer Blending using Aqua Ammonia.  





OFF-SITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS



Worst case offsite consequence analyses (OCA) representing the two regulated substances (i.e. anhydrous ammonia and aqua ammonia) and the four (4) covered processes was completed for this Facility.  The WC OCA for the anhydrous ammonia involves an event that results in the release of the entire contents of a railcar (145,680 lbs).  The WC OCA for the aqua ammonia involved an event that results in the release of the entire contents of the AST (26,250 lbs).  The releases for each regulated substance were modeled to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint.  The anhydrous ammonia release was modeled as a ground level horizontal jet.  The aqua ammonia was modeled as liquid spill and evaporation from the secondary containment.



Three alternative (or more likely to occur) scenarios were completed for the four covered processes.  The release from Covered Process 1 (i.e. railcar) assumes the release from a leaking vapor valve for 60 minutes.  The release from Covered Process 2 (i.e. fertilizer blending using NH3) assumes a 1-minute release from a failed transfer hose.  The release from Covered Processes 3 and 4 (i.e. Aqua S&H and Fertilizer Blending using Aqua) assumes a transfer hose failure within in a containment and then evaporation of the aqua ammonia.



Although these events are classified as alternative scenarios, accidents of this type are mitigated by safety equipment employed on the processes and written operating procedures.



ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Fertilizer Manager implements the risk mana

gement planning process at this Facility.  The Fertilizer Manager is assisted by other Helena staff, as directed.  The Fertilizer Manager is responsible for ensuring that Helena Staff are properly trained in the implementation of the Program Level 2 and 3 Prevention Program.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Helena's Pasco, WA Facility is a non-responding facility. Helena has coordinated emergency response activities with its local emergency response agency and local fire department.

 

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or off-site deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place, in the past five (5) years because of the ammonia operations at the Pasco, WA  Facility.



CONCLUSION



The Risk Management Plan implemented by Helena Chemical Company at the Pasco, WA Facility complies with the requirements of the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r). The RMP will be updated as the Pasco, WA Facility adds, deletes, or changes processes. The Emergency Response Program has been coordinated with the Franklin County LEPC and the Pasco Fire Department.  



NOTE: Sections 4, 5, and 6 of the standard RMP produced by EPA's RMP Submit Program are not applicable to the Pasco, WA Facility.
